description.narrative: The intended impact of the programme is defined at two levels as follows:- Equitable growth, poverty reduction, rule of law and long term stability in Uganda (Super Impact) - Strengthened democratization, protection of human rights, access to justice, peaceful coexistence and improved accountability. (Impact)The outcome that is expected to support the impact are:- Improvements in accountable, responsive, rights-based governance through effective citizen participation coupled with stronger institutions.The outcomes are further aggregated at component level as per recommendations in the AR 2014. A new results framework was approved in September 2015.

Since July 2011 Sweden has, as one of eight development partners, supported the programme Democratic Governance Facility (DGF). In a relatively challenging environment DGF has in a resultsoriented manner, achieved the expected results and provided the basis for joint planning, joint financing and joint implementation of a programme comprising three components:1) Deepening Democracy, 2) Rights, Justice and Peace, and 3) Voice and Accountability. The proposed support refers to a bridging phase between DGF I 2011-2016 and DGF II 2018-2022. The overall assessment is that the DGF programme is well in line with the Swedish strategy for Uganda 2014-2018. Through DGF Sweden has the opportunity to support a large number (85) of state-and non-state actors which operate at local and national levels in order to advance to democratic development, gender and human rights in Uganda. The bridging phase will focus on evaluating DGF phase I and scope and design the framework for DGF II.
Typical examples of activities include; civic education about human rights and democracy, legal aid for women in particular, public campaigns against corruption, advocacy regarding legislation influencing civil society space and transparency in the extractive industries sector, psycho-social support to victims of conflict, training of journalists and production of journalistic content for better accountability and management of human rights abuse complaints.
The Embassy assessed the contribution as highly relevant in the context of Uganda which has seen increased suppression of freedom of assembly, expression and association as well as increased apathy towards both the state and civil society in recent years, particularly in the aftermaths of the general elections in February 2016. The contribution will complement the current portfolio in the area of Access to Justice where a new support is envisaged during 2016 and the area of Freedom of Expression where a new agreement was signed with Hivos at the end of 2015.

Uganda brottas med svaga demokratiska institutioner, utbredd korruption, generellt låg servicenivå inom sociala sektorer som hälsa och utbildning och stora utmaningar att skapa sysselssättning för framförallt unga samt att säkra att den ekonomiska tillväxten kommer fattiga till del. Samtidigt begränsas det demokratiska utrymmet genom inskränkningar för civila samhället avseende grundläggande rättigheter såsom mötes- förenings och yttrandefrihet. Även om antalet organisationer som arbetar med rättighetsfrågor har ökat under en tioårsperiod påverkar detta sammantaget förverkligandet av fördjupad demokrati och ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter i landet.
Sedan juli 2011 har Sverige, som en av åtta givare, gett stöd till programmet ”Democratic Governance Facility” (DGF). DGF har, i en relativt utmanande miljö, på ett ändamålsenligt sätt uppnått förväntade resultat och möjliggjort gemensam planering och finansiering samt gemensamt genomförande av programmet som består av tre komponenter: 1) Fördjupad demokrati, 2) Mänskliga rättigheter, rättstrygghet och fred, och 3) Ansvarsutkrävande. Genom DGF har Sverige möjlighet att, genom stöd till 85 statliga och icke-statliga aktörer som är verksamma på lokal och nationell nivå, fortsatt bidra till stärkt demokrati, jämställdhet och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter i Uganda.
Typiska exempel på aktiviteter är; bred utbildning och information om mänskliga rättigheter och demokrati, juridisk rådgivning till framförallt kvinnor, publika kampanjer mot korruption, påverkansarbete vad gäller lagstiftning i relation till civila samhällets utrymme och för ökad transparens inom utvinningsindustrin, psyko-socialt stöd till konfliktoffer, utbildning av journalister och produktion av journalistiskt innehåll för bättre ansvarsutkrävande samt hantering av MR-övergreppsanmälningar.
Beslutet avser en överbryggningsfas mellan DGF I 2011-2016 och DGF II 2018-2022. Överbryggningsfasen kommer att fokusera på utvärdering av fas I samt design och utformning av fas II. För att bibehålla kontinuitet och långsiktighet kommer DGF partners aktiviteter att fortsätta under överbryggningsfasen.
Det är ambassadens bedömning att det fortsatta stödet till DGF är både effektivt och relevant i den ugandiska kontexten och att det ligger i linje med Sveriges strategi för Uganda 2014-2018.

description.narrative: The period July 2016–December 2017 was an extension of the first phase of the the Democratic Governance Facility (DGF). The contributing Development Partners (DPs)decided to have the extension to support the evolution of DGF’s established partnerships and more closely align component programmes to the post-election political and governance realities of Uganda, to pilot new approaches that build on lessons learned, to evaluate the impact and effectiveness of DGF I programme strategies and partnerships, and to design and appraise a second 5-year phase of the programme. Below are a selection of concrete outputs of the programme as reported in the final report: - Over 5.7 million people were reached with civic education (CE) and voter education. The evaluation of CE delivered through the ordinary model found a high level of knowledge and understanding by citizens on all CE modules that were delivered to them, which enhanced their confidence, knowledge and skills to engage duty bearers on various issues of their interest. - Overall, DGF human rights IPs created awareness among over 8 million people on their legal and human rights and how to protect and claim them. There was, possibly as a result of this, an increase in the number of cases reported and handled by the Uganda Human Rights Commission (UHRC) related to human rights violations. - The implementing partners working on legal aid sensitized over 2.09 million people on legal aid, which was far above the planned target of 700,000 people. They also managed to recover of over UGX 2 billion on behalf of the poor, vulnerable and marginalized people through mediation and court rulings. - In Northern Uganda, the African Youth Initiative Network (AYINET) and the Refugee Law Project (RLP) directly reached a total of 5,214 (2552 M, 2662F) victims of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA)-Uganda government conflict with transitional justice interventions. This reach was above the planned target of 1,014 victims. The interventions included: provision of medical and surgical treatment to war survivors;provision of psychosocial rehabilitation to the survivors of the LRA war; and creation of community awareness about the on-going transitional justice processes. - The anti-corruption partners continued to monitor use of public resources, leading to recovery of billions of money and other misappropriated resources, and reporting of corruption cases to relevant government institutions for action. - At the national level, the Office of the Leader of the Opposition (LoP) was supported to play its oversight role over the executive by producing alternative policy statements. These contributed to shaping government policy direction and inclusion of citizen’s aspirations in government programmes. DGF and the implementing partners also intensified efforts to promote gender equality in the reporting period. One example is the advocacy measures to popularise the Certificate of Gender and Equity, which requires all ministries, departments, and agencies and local governments to include specific gender needs in their budget framework papers and ministerial policy statements. There are also examples from the area of access to justice, support to GBV survivors and more. At the DGF Programme Management Unit (PMU), gender programming was strengthened through cross-component meetings, reflection and shared learning as well as institutionalisation of gender responsive policies and practices. (Sweden also managed to support the office with one Bilateral Associate Expert on gender equality.) Some partners were supported with capacity building in gender mainstreaming, which, according to DGF, has enabled them to design and implement gender responsive policies and practices. Youth is another cross cutting issue of the programme. One example of work done on youth integration is the advocacy work for the aspirations of the National Youth Manifesto as a basis for engagement with policy makers and technocrats over youth issues. All in all, DGF reports that 20 out of the 23 outputs measured managed to meet or exceed the targets.
